was much amused in reading 8. Harker's Ad-
dress to the Federalists of Delaware. wide Del.
Gazette of the esd inst.) The ingenuity mani
tested BY the champion of Jackson and Federalism,
is alarmingty striking. After decrying the De-
mocratic Governors Of this State, their principles
and their measures-after having denounced the
ascendency of the Democratic Party as the most
injurious and anarchcal, destructive both to the
I. honor and interests Of the State," and express
sing and implying that neither knowledge nor in
tegrty characterized their minds or guided their
measures, that the Democratic policy was sub
versiye of all goodness and productive of all ev,-
after all this, at the close of his " address, he ex-
hoi all good and substantial Federalists to vote
for Jackson, because he is Democrat "trom
principle" How Mr. Harker can deprecate De-
mocracy and all its advocates in one paragraph
and then recommend Democrat " from principle"
as proper candidate for the Presidential chair, in
anothsr--on the same day andin the same address
is thing which can be reconciled in no mind but
his own. He holds up Democracy as the Demon
of Destruction, yet in the same breath bids his
friends give Democrat from principle, their
suffrages. This is all Of piece with Mr.. Harker


Think not, Messrs. Editors, that doubt or de.
precate the soundness Of Gen Jackson's princi
pIes of Democracy. / revere them and consider
them as his highest and most reasonable and sub
stantal recommendations to tho Presidency. 1t
he were not Democrat, all that he has done would
never have brought him into the field as candi-
date for the "hishest gift Of the People" All
wish to incucate expose is the ingenuity (incon-
sstency) Of the Editor of the Gazette.


But further. Mr.. Harker's objections to Mr..
Adams are the strongest reasons for his support
and election by the Democrats Of this State and all
others. Mr.. Adams has been for long time the
most powerful opponent of Federalism. The etfi-
cient opposition which he urged against the Fed
eral party during the last war must ever be remem-
bered with gratitude by the present Democratic
ascertlencv. When Federalism, aristocracy's
hopeful child, reared its hypocrtical and treacher-
Gus head amongst US, plotting the dismemberment
of the Union and the destruction Of Republican
ism, JOHN @. ADAMS stood as mighty champion
welded the powerful influence of his knowledge
and talents in their defence Federalism feels
that he had much to do in her downfall-he has
wounded her deeply and still, with malignity,
she breathes through her agents, the bitterest i'm
FOR THE wATcHMAN.

precautions against him. These deeds which he
has achieved for his party should secure for him
tie cheerful vote Of every Democrat


Another overwhelming objection of Mr.. Harker
against Mr.. Adams, is the manner of his election.
He was chosen BY majority of the House Of Re-
presentatves, in the mode prescribed by the Con-
stitution of the United States, and this is reason
why he should not be supported, by Mr.. Harker
and his party which he is pleased to serve. Where
is the man who is afraid to trust the principles and
forms Of our Constitution? 1t has served US faith
fully and advantageously for many years, and we
should not break it to pieces heap abuse upon it
unadvisedly. / must acknowledge the present
mode of electing the President and Vice President
Of the United States is, in my opinion, liable to
some objections; but still, in the late election Of
J. Q. Adams, the Representatives Of the People
acted constitutionally and honestly. | think the
Representative should speak the voice Of his Con-
stituents; and if Representative had consulted
his, the cote Of Delaware aCould not haze been
THROWN AWAY. But is it any objection to Pre-
silent that he has been constitutionally elected ?
1t may dsqualify man, it may shake his integrity
and dull his intellect, in Mr.. Harker's opinion.
but every reasonable man must ridicule such an
opinion MIR. Harker has many queer notions,
and this is one Of them, that Mr. Adams should
not be elected to the next Presidency, because he
was chosen in the manner prescribed BY the Con-
stitution.


But Mr.. Harker's reasons why Federaists should
vote for Jackson should be powerful stimuli in
Democrats to oppose him. Jackson's policy, says
Mr.. Harker, is to give the Federalists distinction
and efficiency in the government she is to be the
patron of that party who threw obstacles in the
way Of !. the second war of independence, ,"-he
is to befriend those traitors Of their land who
would have sacrificed US to the oppression of Bri-
tain sin word Federalism and its friends are to
|be fostered under his paternal care, and in time
regain that destructive strength which once made
them as terrific as they are now weak. If Democ-
racy is worth preserving, all its friends should
unite in giving their suffrages to its firm and able
friend and advocate. John Q. Adams has been
acknowledged by Federalists as their most vio-
lent opposershe has done bis country invaluable
service in assisting to crush the destroyer of Re-
publican Liberty-and should ever be remembered
with gratitude by the Democratic party for the SER
vices he has rendered their party, and the wisdom


with which he has guided the councils Of his coun-
try. X.

,,h.ntments, recourse must be had to permanent
;nee and inclined planes, Just as recourse IS had
locks for canals; but here again the Rail Road
,.,en has great advantage; the inclined plane
psuses no delay, while locking creates great
heal" cray r Ao' ana low


,rbs Rail Road.-The Cincinnati Ohio CONNER
iii Register, thus speaks Of the Rail Road pro-
ct:-a The citizens of Baltimore are all excite
nept, on the subject of a Rail Road from baltimore
ID thc Ohio river. large meeting was lately held
h that enterprising city. at which committee was
nnonted to take the subject into consideration,
Fr,end has lust furnished US with the report, and
se have read it with the deepest feelings OF graft
Ecaton. We have long since been satisfied of the
bracticability and superiority of Rail Roads, over
very other means of transportation, and whilst
[es;dent in another State we exerted ourselves to
|be utmost in trying to render the Rail Road sys-
em more popular and acceptable than canal.
The result of Mr.. Strickland's visit to England,
las confirmed our prepossessons in favor OF this
pecies Of internal improvement, over all others.


e have lately joined in the cry in favor Of canals
because we considered this was as far as public
oninion was as yet prepared to go. Canals are
Certainly great deal better than turnpikes, pre-
Earious water courses but Rail Roads are as much
uperior to Canals as Canals are to the Pennsylva-
|bia Turnpke.-We therefore hail the spirit that is


sng in Baltimore, we are pleased that such an
knterprisng place should have taken up the idea.
md we almost rejoice that the affairs of that city
ave been so threatened, as to render the attempt
Indispensable to her prosperity. The trade and


reductions of the inexhaustible and fertile plains
bf the West have become the grand object of con-


est for our Atlantic cities. The struggle is proof
81 their penetration; the game they play is a glo-
ious one the palm of victory will be splendid !;
hey who achieve it will be placed on the flow tide
bf fortune, and boundless wealth and influence will
be the natural result. The West herself, in the
went of success, will burst into new state of ex-
stence and find that although too long neglected,
She is doomed to take rank, equal in natural ad
Gantages, to our hitherto, more happily situated
Atantic borders. With our Rivers and Canals
&one the destnes of Ohio bid fair to be brilliant.
But we are not dsinterested observers OF the strug
gles of our Eastern brethren. We say to them
( God speed YOU Let them who " win US, wear
us." We are heartily tired of Louisiana Monop-
&oly; it cannot be possible that the immense pro-
ductions Of the almost boundless region ofthe West,
are to be doomed always to be filtered through the
commission houses of Orleans, or subjected to the
precarious market of that city. 1t would be mat
ter of singular speculation however, IT after the
nagniicent and praise worthy eyertions Of New
York, and in spite of the apatetc wealth of Phila-
delphia, Baltimore, "litle Baltimore" should step
Pin, and carry off the prize"

in Georgetown, Sussex County, Delaware, Of the fol-
lowing description and dimensions. will be received by the

The building to be stories high, fory-fve feet in

caves The materials OF the walls to be OF the best bricks
that can be had in the vicinity Of the place. except the
show Of the ont wall which must be OF good Phadepha
paving bricks. The roof 10 be Of good shlHgles.


Through the House, from front to rear. to be passage
of ten feet in width in each story. equally dividing the
whole with substantial doors at the extremtes of the low
er passage.


substantial for the prison spartmen the walls where
Of must be % inches thickness the inner forming
one side Of each entry 90 inches and the subdivdng
walls Of the several apartments 13 inches. of which apart
ments there will be four in each story and each one to
have fire pace and into the windows thereof must be
affixed strong gratcs and the doors to be strong and
corresponding The rafters and oss strong and the at
ter not than six inches apart. The floors of the
entries stairway and apartments to be OF inch oak and
the 6nsh of the whole to be in like substantial and cor
responding manner.


Of the oher division, designed for the keepers
modaon the outer wall will be 13 inches in thickness
the flooring of good pine, with three
each foor and fire place in each the whole to be Of
good and suitable materials, finished in plain substantial
manner the style and construction whereof to be what
mon and comfortable Brick dwellings generally are.
The Commissioners wish to know the extra rate that
would be asked to build it of Philadelphia bricks, which
NAV be brought TO Milton, only miles distant, by water.

.Naw Fork, March 27.
The ship Chancellor.-We regret to state that
the supply ship laden with provisions and clothing
for the suffering non-combatants Of Greece, has
been compelled to put back in distress.


PHILADELPHIA, MARoH 23.
We are informed that private letters have been
received here, which give accounts Of the breaking
up Of Mr.. Ovens establishment, at New Harmony
in Indiana. The protector, it is said, has gone to
New Orleans, and the members Of the society have
dispersed. 1t is said also that he complains bit
terly of the unmanageable, heterogeneous materi-
ais that he had to work with, in his essay, to es
tablish new form Of civilized society. Press.
Washington, March 2s.-The Board of Com
missioners and Arbtrators, under the first article
of the Treaty of Client, adjourned on Monday e.
venng last sine die-its functions have been su-
perseded by the late Convention between the Uni
ted States and Great Britain on that subject.

Maryland, it is believed will give Mr.. Adams

From the Cincinnati Gazette.

Troubles in Canada.-For several days past
there have been alarming reports in circulation of
connections in our neighboring province Of Upper
province will come within the operation Of the alien
law. It would appear that they are resolved not
to submit to it. And it is reported that liberty
poles, ON which were displayed the American flag,
have been raised in several places. In York, a
liberty pole was raised, and the American flag
waved on it, within few rods Of the Capitol. 1t
was promptly put down by the government party.
large force was then collected from the neighbor
ing country, and the pole and flag were again rails
ed. These may be exaggerated reports; but we
think there is something to make them out of.

PIRACY-An article the death Of Archbishop Car
roll which has been forth to the world original
communication" and which has been republished in
various newspapers specimen of the ability with which
the american Quarterly Reve promises to be conducted
will be found, by reference TO the files Of the Federal
Gazette be nothing than the amalgamation oftw
articles one of which, originally appeared in that paper
Dec 4h 1915, and the other repubshed on the 7h
Dec 1915 from the Telegraph One, If not both OF the
articles written by gentleman OF Baltimore, several
years since deceased The article in the review is evident
y copied from above many instances alteration
whatever being made in the phraseology Where the
language varied from the original to humble appre
hension the change is not for the better.


Small Por.-The Rutland (vt.) Herald an
nounces the decease of Mr.. Walker (paper maker)
of small pox, caught from imported rags. Mr.
WIS. two children had taken the disease. Mea-
sures had been adopted by the town authorities to
prevent the spreading Of the contagon. The life
Of father has been thus sacrificed to neglect Of
vaccination, and his children put in jeopardy.

full articles.article:
was much amused in reading 8. Harker's Ad-
dress to the Federalists of Delaware. wide Del.
Gazette of the esd inst.) The ingenuity mani
tested BY the champion of Jackson and Federalism,
is alarmingty striking. After decrying the De-
mocratic Governors Of this State, their principles
and their measures-after having denounced the
ascendency of the Democratic Party as the most
injurious and anarchcal, destructive both to the
I. honor and interests Of the State," and express
sing and implying that neither knowledge nor in
tegrty characterized their minds or guided their
measures, that the Democratic policy was sub
versiye of all goodness and productive of all ev,-
after all this, at the close of his " address, he ex-
hoi all good and substantial Federalists to vote
for Jackson, because he is Democrat "trom
principle" How Mr. Harker can deprecate De-
mocracy and all its advocates in one paragraph
and then recommend Democrat " from principle"
as proper candidate for the Presidential chair, in
anothsr--on the same day andin the same address
is thing which can be reconciled in no mind but
his own. He holds up Democracy as the Demon
of Destruction, yet in the same breath bids his
friends give Democrat from principle, their
suffrages. This is all Of piece with Mr.. Harker


Think not, Messrs. Editors, that doubt or de.
precate the soundness Of Gen Jackson's princi
pIes of Democracy. / revere them and consider
them as his highest and most reasonable and sub
stantal recommendations to tho Presidency. 1t
he were not Democrat, all that he has done would
never have brought him into the field as candi-
date for the "hishest gift Of the People" All
wish to incucate expose is the ingenuity (incon-
sstency) Of the Editor of the Gazette.


But further. Mr.. Harker's objections to Mr..
Adams are the strongest reasons for his support
and election by the Democrats Of this State and all
others. Mr.. Adams has been for long time the
most powerful opponent of Federalism. The etfi-
cient opposition which he urged against the Fed
eral party during the last war must ever be remem-
bered with gratitude by the present Democratic
ascertlencv. When Federalism, aristocracy's
hopeful child, reared its hypocrtical and treacher-
Gus head amongst US, plotting the dismemberment
of the Union and the destruction Of Republican
ism, JOHN @. ADAMS stood as mighty champion
welded the powerful influence of his knowledge
and talents in their defence Federalism feels
that he had much to do in her downfall-he has
wounded her deeply and still, with malignity,
she breathes through her agents, the bitterest i'm

precautions against him. These deeds which he
has achieved for his party should secure for him
tie cheerful vote Of every Democrat


Another overwhelming objection of Mr.. Harker
against Mr.. Adams, is the manner of his election.
He was chosen BY majority of the House Of Re-
presentatves, in the mode prescribed by the Con-
stitution of the United States, and this is reason
why he should not be supported, by Mr.. Harker
and his party which he is pleased to serve. Where
is the man who is afraid to trust the principles and
forms Of our Constitution? 1t has served US faith
fully and advantageously for many years, and we
should not break it to pieces heap abuse upon it
unadvisedly. / must acknowledge the present
mode of electing the President and Vice President
Of the United States is, in my opinion, liable to
some objections; but still, in the late election Of
J. Q. Adams, the Representatives Of the People
acted constitutionally and honestly. | think the
Representative should speak the voice Of his Con-
stituents; and if Representative had consulted
his, the cote Of Delaware aCould not haze been
THROWN AWAY. But is it any objection to Pre-
silent that he has been constitutionally elected ?
1t may dsqualify man, it may shake his integrity
and dull his intellect, in Mr.. Harker's opinion.
but every reasonable man must ridicule such an
opinion MIR. Harker has many queer notions,
and this is one Of them, that Mr. Adams should
not be elected to the next Presidency, because he
was chosen in the manner prescribed BY the Con-
stitution.


But Mr.. Harker's reasons why Federaists should
vote for Jackson should be powerful stimuli in
Democrats to oppose him. Jackson's policy, says
Mr.. Harker, is to give the Federalists distinction
and efficiency in the government she is to be the
patron of that party who threw obstacles in the
way Of !. the second war of independence, ,"-he
is to befriend those traitors Of their land who
would have sacrificed US to the oppression of Bri-
tain sin word Federalism and its friends are to
|be fostered under his paternal care, and in time
regain that destructive strength which once made
them as terrific as they are now weak. If Democ-
racy is worth preserving, all its friends should
unite in giving their suffrages to its firm and able
friend and advocate. John Q. Adams has been
acknowledged by Federalists as their most vio-
lent opposershe has done bis country invaluable
service in assisting to crush the destroyer of Re-
publican Liberty-and should ever be remembered
with gratitude by the Democratic party for the SER
vices he has rendered their party, and the wisdom


with which he has guided the councils Of his coun-
try. X.

we're males of 90 years and upwards, and l142
were under 90 years, making total 1912 males.
985 were females of 90 years and upwards, and
962 under 20 years, making total of 1947 females.
347 of the deaths took place in the Aims House
and 500 were People Of Color. The Births in the
same year in the City and Liberties, we're 1926
Males-3214 Females, making the total number of
Births 6740, being an excess over Deaths, of 1889.





The total number Of deaths in Baltimore during
the year 1896, was 1922. The greatest number Of
deaths in one month was 277, in July-the small
lest number, Is, in November. Of the above
number of deaths. 500 were under one year OF age

,,h.ntments, recourse must be had to permanent
;nee and inclined planes, Just as recourse IS had
locks for canals; but here again the Rail Road
,.,en has great advantage; the inclined plane
psuses no delay, while locking creates great
heal" cray r Ao' ana low


,rbs Rail Road.-The Cincinnati Ohio CONNER
iii Register, thus speaks Of the Rail Road pro-
ct:-a The citizens of Baltimore are all excite
nept, on the subject of a Rail Road from baltimore
ID thc Ohio river. large meeting was lately held
h that enterprising city. at which committee was
nnonted to take the subject into consideration,
Fr,end has lust furnished US with the report, and
se have read it with the deepest feelings OF graft
Ecaton. We have long since been satisfied of the
bracticability and superiority of Rail Roads, over
very other means of transportation, and whilst
[es;dent in another State we exerted ourselves to
|be utmost in trying to render the Rail Road sys-
em more popular and acceptable than canal.
The result of Mr.. Strickland's visit to England,
las confirmed our prepossessons in favor OF this
pecies Of internal improvement, over all others.


e have lately joined in the cry in favor Of canals
because we considered this was as far as public
oninion was as yet prepared to go. Canals are
Certainly great deal better than turnpikes, pre-
Earious water courses but Rail Roads are as much
uperior to Canals as Canals are to the Pennsylva-
|bia Turnpke.-We therefore hail the spirit that is


sng in Baltimore, we are pleased that such an
knterprisng place should have taken up the idea.
md we almost rejoice that the affairs of that city
ave been so threatened, as to render the attempt
Indispensable to her prosperity. The trade and


reductions of the inexhaustible and fertile plains
bf the West have become the grand object of con-


est for our Atlantic cities. The struggle is proof
81 their penetration; the game they play is a glo-
ious one the palm of victory will be splendid !;
hey who achieve it will be placed on the flow tide
bf fortune, and boundless wealth and influence will
be the natural result. The West herself, in the
went of success, will burst into new state of ex-
stence and find that although too long neglected,
She is doomed to take rank, equal in natural ad
Gantages, to our hitherto, more happily situated
Atantic borders. With our Rivers and Canals
&one the destnes of Ohio bid fair to be brilliant.
But we are not dsinterested observers OF the strug
gles of our Eastern brethren. We say to them
( God speed YOU Let them who " win US, wear
us." We are heartily tired of Louisiana Monop-
&oly; it cannot be possible that the immense pro-
ductions Of the almost boundless region ofthe West,
are to be doomed always to be filtered through the
commission houses of Orleans, or subjected to the
precarious market of that city. 1t would be mat
ter of singular speculation however, IT after the
nagniicent and praise worthy eyertions Of New
York, and in spite of the apatetc wealth of Phila-
delphia, Baltimore, "litle Baltimore" should step
Pin, and carry off the prize"

in Georgetown, Sussex County, Delaware, Of the fol-
lowing description and dimensions. will be received by the

The building to be stories high, fory-fve feet in
fon fifty feet width and twenty feet in height 10 the
caves The materials OF the walls to be OF the best bricks
that can be had in the vicinity Of the place. except the
show Of the ont wall which must be OF good Phadepha
paving bricks. The roof 10 be Of good shlHgles.


Through the House, from front to rear. to be passage
of ten feet in width in each story. equally dividing the
whole with substantial doors at the extremtes of the low
er passage.


substantial for the prison spartmen the walls where
Of must be % inches thickness the inner forming
one side Of each entry 90 inches and the subdivdng
walls Of the several apartments 13 inches. of which apart
ments there will be four in each story and each one to
have fire pace and into the windows thereof must be
affixed strong gratcs and the doors to be strong and
corresponding The rafters and oss strong and the at
ter not than six inches apart. The floors of the
entries stairway and apartments to be OF inch oak and
the 6nsh of the whole to be in like substantial and cor
responding manner.


Of the oher division, designed for the keepers
modaon the outer wall will be 13 inches in thickness
the flooring of good pine, with three
each foor and fire place in each the whole to be Of
good and suitable materials, finished in plain substantial
manner the style and construction whereof to be what
mon and comfortable Brick dwellings generally are.
The Commissioners wish to know the extra rate that
would be asked to build it of Philadelphia bricks, which
NAV be brought TO Milton, only miles distant, by water.
Proposals will be received until the 25th day Of May
ne 1t, addressed TO


Lewcs, Del

full articles.headline: NEw-YoRK. MARCH 26.
full articles.article:
NEw-YoRK, MARCH 26.
enforcement of the Presidents Proctamation.-
We understand that one or two British vessels.
arrived yesterday from British ports. were order
ed off.


.Naw Fork, March 27.
The ship Chancellor.-We regret to state that
the supply ship laden with provisions and clothing
for the suffering non-combatants Of Greece, has
been compelled to put back in distress.


PHILADELPHIA, MARoH 23.
We are informed that private letters have been
received here, which give accounts Of the breaking
up Of Mr.. Ovens establishment, at New Harmony
in Indiana. The protector, it is said, has gone to
New Orleans, and the members Of the society have
dispersed. 1t is said also that he complains bit
terly of the unmanageable, heterogeneous materi-
ais that he had to work with, in his essay, to es
tablish new form Of civilized society. Press.
Washington, March 2s.-The Board of Com
missioners and Arbtrators, under the first article
of the Treaty of Client, adjourned on Monday e.
venng last sine die-its functions have been su-
perseded by the late Convention between the Uni
ted States and Great Britain on that subject.

noticed of education under the patronage OF
the American Board of for Foreign Missions

The whole quantity of domestic cotton manufac-
lures sold in Philadelphia in the years 1904 S, and
6, only amounted to the sum Of Sl7,670. Itis
now estimated that the whole amount sold there
varies but little from four millions annually and
is rapidly increasing.

Eatract Of letter from gentleman Of the first


respectability in .Marytand, to friend in Dela-


vare, dated Goth March, 1927.


Maryland, it is believed will give Mr.. Adams
strong vote. 1t is the opinion of intelligent men
that but one of our districts can, with certainty, be
assigned to the Jackson interest. Most of them,
however, are claimed by our adversaries. This is
quite in accordance with their system Of bold calcu-
lation and confident assertion. Rely upon it, they
are preparing for desperate effort. That the
People can be seduced into an opposition, tchich


felc leaders haze ercited to secure to Themselves
the Offices to which they aspire, is matter which
am unwilling to believe, until the event shall de-
monstrate it.o

4 We are informed that Gen. M'Ifatton, the Jack
son representative of the adjacent district IN Ken
< 8tucky contributes pretty decent subsidy to the
Telegraph. Something like three hundred packa-
&gcs have aeen received at one Post Ohice, IN the
5countv of Grant, all frankcd by Gen. MsHatton,
7 and containing either United States Telegraph,
or miserable dull ten page pamphlet, giving a
4 4puEing memoir Of Gen. Jackson This is doing
an excellent business. Gen. M.Hatton, who pos
sesses no single qualification to render him useful
Hin Congress-, gets eight dollars per day from the
public Treasury. With this he buys newspapers
and pamphlets that support Gen. Jackson. and
crowds the public mails with them, distributing
Them, in particular sections of the country, to aid
the opposition, and promote his own reelection.
Others, besides the supporters Of the adminstra-
K ton, are, by these MEANS nourshed with Treasury
Even the immaculate, sweet scented Tee.
8graph obtains taste in addition to the supplies
upon mail contracts enjoyed by its Editor.

full articles.headline: Bufalo, March g.
full articles.article:
Troubles in Canada.-For several days past
there have been alarming reports in circulation of
connections in our neighboring province Of Upper
province will come within the operation Of the alien
law. It would appear that they are resolved not
to submit to it. And it is reported that liberty
poles, ON which were displayed the American flag,
have been raised in several places. In York, a
liberty pole was raised, and the American flag
waved on it, within few rods Of the Capitol. 1t
was promptly put down by the government party.
large force was then collected from the neighbor
ing country, and the pole and flag were again rails
ed. These may be exaggerated reports; but we
think there is something to make them out of.

TCoMmUHIcATRD
full articles.article:
PIRACY-An article the death Of Archbishop Car
roll which has been forth to the world original
communication" and which has been republished in
various newspapers specimen of the ability with which
the american Quarterly Reve promises to be conducted
will be found, by reference TO the files Of the Federal
Gazette be nothing than the amalgamation oftw
articles one of which, originally appeared in that paper
Dec 4h 1915, and the other repubshed on the 7h
Dec 1915 from the Telegraph One, If not both OF the
articles written by gentleman OF Baltimore, several
years since deceased The article in the review is evident
y copied from above many instances alteration
whatever being made in the phraseology Where the
language varied from the original to humble appre
hension the change is not for the better.


Small Por.-The Rutland (vt.) Herald an
nounces the decease of Mr.. Walker (paper maker)
of small pox, caught from imported rags. Mr.
WIS. two children had taken the disease. Mea-
sures had been adopted by the town authorities to
prevent the spreading Of the contagon. The life
Of father has been thus sacrificed to neglect Of
vaccination, and his children put in jeopardy.

Fire-A fire broke out On Monday last in a
nouse adjoining the new brick Presbyterian Church
ln Paterson, III, which destroyed the house in
Which the fire originated. the church, and some
Cher buildings.
